RECREATIONAL.summary: It is not legal for adults to possess cannabis in South Carolina. State law classifies marijuana as a controlled substance, and possession of any amount for recreational use is a criminal offense punishable by jail time and fines. There are no general exceptions for adult use; only a narrow exception exists for certain low-THC, high-CBD products prescribed for severe epilepsy.
RECREATIONAL.gov_quote: "It is unlawful for any person to possess or have under his control a controlled substance unless obtained pursuant to a valid prescription or order of a practitioner." (S.C. Code Ann. ยง 44-53-370)

MEDICAL.summary: It is not legal for medical marijuana patients to possess cannabis in South Carolina, except for a very limited exception allowing certain epilepsy patients to possess low-THC, high-CBD oil with a physician's certification. There is no comprehensive medical marijuana program, and possession of cannabis by patients for other medical conditions remains a criminal offense.
MEDICAL.gov_quote: for persons, or the persons' parents, legal guardians, or other caretakers, who have received a written certification from a physician licensed in this State that the person has been diagnosed by a physician as having Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, Dravet Syndrome, also known as "severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy", or any other severe form of epilepsy that is not adequately treated by traditional medical therapies, the substance cannabidiol, a nonpsychoactive cannabinoid, or any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of any plant of the genus cannabis that contains nine-tenths of one percent or less of tetrahydrocannabinol and more than fifteen percent of cannabidiol.
